SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems.

Mr. Brian reports feeling out of sorts lately, with fatigue, lightheadedness, and occasional bloating. He attributes this to the change in seasons and recent home construction projects. He has been experiencing these symptoms for about five weeks. The patient has been adhering to his medications but has struggled with his diet due to the construction on his kitchen, leading to eating out more frequently and not always choosing healthy options.

Mr. Brian denies fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. He endorses shortness of breath when exerting energy and slight chest cramps that resolve after about an hour. He also reports a slight cough.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Positive fatigue and lightheadedness. No fever or chills.
• Cardiovascular: Positive for occasional bloating and chest cramps.
• Respiratory: Positive for shortness of breath and slight cough.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Vital signs within normal limits.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to about 8 centimeters.
• Cardiovascular: 3 out of 6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in the lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in the lungs.

Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with congestive heart failure and hypertension.

Congestive Heart Failure.
• Medical Reasoning: Patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam findings and chest X-ray.
• Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Patient to weigh himself daily and report any weight gain or shortness of breath. Order a new echocardiogram.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure appears to be well-managed at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Patient to continue monitoring blood pressure at home and report any elevated readings through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She reports that she was changing a light bulb on a ladder yesterday and had a stumble, twisting her knee as she tried to catch her fall. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help much. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a rhinoplasty. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial portion of the knee, over the medial meniscus area. Pain is elicited with flexion and valgus stressing of the knee. Normal sensation is present in the lower extremity. No calf pain is reported.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the left knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present, but overall alignment is normal.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus sprain or strain of the right knee.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her in a knee brace and provide crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for reevaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI at that time. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, to be taken every 6 hours with food, for a two-week supply.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. This happened on Saturday morning, and he felt a pop in his lower back. He had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved, and it has been stiff ever since. He has taken Tylenol, ibuprofen, and used icy heat, but it did not seem to help. He experienced tingling in his toes on his right foot until Sunday afternoon.

Regarding his diabetes, he admits to having a sweet tooth and not having the best diet recently. He plans to improve his eating habits.

Regarding his hypertension, he monitors his blood pressure readings at home during the week but tends to forget on weekends. He is taking his medication.

Regarding his osteoarthritis, it gets aggravated occasionally, but it has been manageable.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Denies fever, chills, nausea, or vomiting.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain. Denies chest pain.
• Neurological: Endorses tingling in toes on the right foot, resolved on Sunday afternoon.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic heart murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the lumbar spine. Pain with flexion and extension of the back. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

X-ray lumbar spine, ordered and obtained in the office today, is unremarkable with good bony alignment.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Acute lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing the area and avoid strenuous activity.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer to physical therapy for further evaluation and treatment.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: His recent hemoglobin A1c was 8, indicating suboptimal control.
• Additional Testing: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are running on the high side.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is managing his knee arthritis well and does not require further workup at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current management.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam.

Regarding his depression, he has been on Prozac and reports no recent incidents. He has been managing his depression well with medication.

Regarding his hypertension, he is on Norvasc and reports taking it regularly during the week but occasionally forgets on weekends. His blood pressure in the office today is 120/80.

He had a lobectomy a couple of years ago and reports no significant issues with shortness of breath, except during high pollen season and when running in humid conditions.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion due to pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain. Reports occasional chest pounding during exercise.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath with exertion.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression, managed with medication.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.
• Head and Neck: Pain to palpation of sinuses.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerning findings related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is doing well on Prozac 20 mg daily.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue current medication.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Refill Prozac prescription.

2. Prior lobectomy.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is exercising regularly and has no significant respiratory issues.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon is needed.

3. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is well-controlled in the office today.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc as prescribed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain after a skiing accident. She reports that her finger was bent back while skiing over moguls four days ago.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Constipation
Appendectomy at age 18

EXAM:

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right index finger obtained on today's visit show no fractures and normal alignment.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week. If the pain does not improve, the patient is advised to call and return for a follow-up. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper, a 65-year-old female, presents as a new patient referred by Diane Nelson for long-standing iron deficiency anemia. The patient reports being anemic since the age of 13. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. Ms. Cooper has been experiencing fatigue, feverishness with chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, headaches, and increased anxiety and depression. She had a hysterectomy in 1996 and her last colonoscopy was approximately 5-6 years ago with normal results.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Iron deficiency anemia.
Hysterectomy in 1996.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Alcohol consumption: occasional, once or twice a year.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Ferrous sulfate 25mg tablets, twice daily.
Over-the-counter vitamin B12.

PHYSICAL EXAM

General: Patient appears well-nourished and in no acute distress.
Cardiovascular: Heart sounds normal.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, and non-distended.

ASSESSMENT

Iron deficiency anemia.

PLAN

1. Upper endoscopy and colonoscopy: Schedule these procedures to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.

2. Hematologist referral: Send a referral to Dr. Flores, a hematologist, for further evaluation and management.

3. Iron supplementation: Continue ferrous sulfate 25mg tablets twice daily with orange juice for improved absorption. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 8-12 weeks.

INSTRUCTIONS

Schedule upper endoscopy and colonoscopy appointments. Follow bowel prep instructions provided. Schedule an appointment with the hematologist, Dr. Flores. Call the clinic with any questions or worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. The patient was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention. Mr. Ward initially presented to his primary care provider on 3/1/21 with complaints of worsening headaches over the past few months. His past clinical history is unremarkable. Workup for headaches included brain MRI and serology, which incidentally discovered the pituitary lesion. Pertinent labs and radiology studies were reviewed, including a pituitary hormone profile showing a low TSH and an MRI revealing a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm.

The patient reports headaches located behind his eyes, described as a dull nagging ache, with a gradual onset and worsening severity over the past three months. The headaches are worse in the morning and last a few hours at a time. No other associated symptoms were reported, such as fever, neck stiffness, or numbness. The patient has recently noticed difficulty with peripheral vision, leading to bumping into door frames.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Unremarkable.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Occupation: Computer programmer.
Marital status: Married for 25 years.
Alcohol, tobacco, and drug use: None.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None.

EXAMINATION

The patient is alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent. Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities. Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

ASSESSMENT

• Pituitary adenoma.

PLAN

1. Recommend surgical intervention to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa due to symptomatic optic chiasmal compression.
2. Refer the patient to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to assess peripheral vision before and after surgery.
3. Discuss the risks associated with surgery, including anesthesia risks and potential complications.
4. Schedule surgery and pre-surgery visual field test with the surgery scheduler.

The patient is advised to call if any questions arise.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53 y.o. female who presents today for evaluation of chest pain and difficulty swallowing that occurred in October 2020. She reports that the chest pain lasted for four days and was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone. The pain was sharp and worsened with eating. She also experienced difficulty swallowing during this time. The patient visited the ER, where they performed an EKG and blood tests, all of which were normal. The ER suspected a GI issue and referred her to our clinic. Since the initial episode, the patient reports that her symptoms have resolved.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Uterine fibroids.
Anemia.
Esophagitis (suspected).

Surgical
Cholecystectomy (gallbladder removal).

SOCIAL HISTORY

No information provided.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of GI problems.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

No information provided.

ALLERGIES

No known allergies.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Negative for abdominal pain, abnormal bowel movements, and ongoing chest pain or difficulty swallowing. Positive for mild tenderness in the upper abdominal quadrants during physical examination.

PHYSICAL EXAM

The patient has mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No other abnormalities were noted during the exam.

ASSESSMENT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020, with possible etiologies including GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal issues, and anxiety. The patient's symptoms have resolved since the initial episode, and it is suspected that anxiety related to a job transition may have contributed to her condition.

PLAN

1. The patient has elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any recurrence or change.
2. If the patient experiences additional episodes of pain or other concerning symptoms, an EGD (upper endoscopy) will be scheduled to evaluate her esophagus and stomach.
3. The patient will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Kidney evaluation for Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for kidney evaluation. She is a twin, born at 34 weeks and 3 days, with a birth weight of 4 pounds, 8 ounces. The patient has a history of feeding difficulties, gastroesophageal reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will be starting speech therapy soon. Katherine has also seen an orthopedic specialist, ophthalmologist, and audiologist. The family was informed that individuals with Smith-Magenis Syndrome may have kidney anomalies and leg problems.

The patient has approximately 8 to 10 wet diapers in a 24-hour period. She drinks a combination of pea protein milk, water, and diluted juice. Katherine's twin sister is doing well and is slightly taller but of similar weight.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Smith-Magenis Syndrome.
Prematurity (34 weeks and 3 days).
Gastroesophageal reflux.

FAMILY HISTORY

No family history of kidney failure, dialysis, or transplant.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined. Eyes are small appearing. Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms. Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT

Smith-Magenis Syndrome with potential congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.

PLAN

1. Obtain a kidney ultrasound today for screening purposes.
2. If abnormalities are found on the kidney ultrasound, determine next steps and future follow-up at the town center location, as the family lives in Dallas, Georgia.
3. If the ultrasound is normal, no further follow-up with nephrology is needed.

INSTRUCTIONS

Complete kidney ultrasound today. The clinic will call with the results and provide further instructions if necessary.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her right arm. The patient reports severe pain, rated as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen, which provided minimal relief. The patient denies any previous injuries to her right arm.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain and swelling.
Neurological: Mild tingling in fingers, no numbness.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
RR: 20
Temp: 97.2°F
SPO2: Not reported.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: No carotid bruit, no thyromegaly, no adenopathy.
Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Extremities: Palpable pulses, no lower edema.
MSK: Right wrist with obvious swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness on palpation. Pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Limited ability to make a fist. Bony crepitus present.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist reveals a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have discussed with the patient her current symptoms and diagnosis. I have explained to her that she has a Colles' fracture and will require surgery. In the meantime, we will provide her with a brace for her right wrist. I have prescribed 50 mg of Ultram every six hours for pain management. The patient will undergo surgery and stay overnight for observation. Post-surgery, the patient will wear the brace for six weeks and attend physical therapy three times a week. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled in one month to assess her progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to contact the office if her pain worsens or if she has any concerns before her follow-up appointment.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, currently on Lisinopril 20 mg.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg
Heart rate: Not provided
Respiration: Not provided
No fever.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chest pain, and shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain, swelling, and discomfort during movement.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort. Lungs clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Examination: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Right knee pain with flexion and extension. Pain to palpation on the medial aspect of the knee. Edema and effusion present.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed. No fractures or bony abnormalities were found.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient experienced a fall and reported a popping sensation in the knee, with subsequent pain and swelling.
- Medical Treatment: Ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and inflammation. Knee brace for support. Ice therapy 20 minutes, 3-4 times daily. Elevation and rest for the affected leg.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is elevated at 150/70 mmHg, and they have a history of hypertension.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg. Refer to nutritionist for dietary counseling to help reduce sodium intake and improve overall diet.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and suspects it might be related. The patient states he is very active and has experienced occasional aches and pains before that usually resolve with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant and worsens with pressure. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder and denies it radiates down into the left arm. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping secondary to the pain. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and instability.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain and instability. The patient reports that the pain occurs occasionally, less than once a day, and is accompanied by a sensation of the knee giving out. The pain is described as internal and affecting the whole kneecap area. The patient denies any history of injury or trauma to the knee and has not taken any medications for pain, as the pain does not last long. The patient is concerned about the knee instability affecting her ability to participate in an upcoming trip involving walking and line dancing.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left knee pain and instability. Denies right knee pain.

Cardiovascular: Reports taking blood pressure medication regularly.

Endocrine: Reports taking metformin for diabetes management.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base.

Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

MSK: Examination of the left knee: No ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation. Full range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain and instability, likely due to arthritis.
2. Hypertension, controlled with medication.
3. Diabetes mellitus, managed with metformin.

PLAN

1. For the left knee pain and instability, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider initiating physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee.
2. Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension management and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order a hemoglobin A1C and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and potential adjustments to metformin dosage. Encourage the patient to continue taking metformin as prescribed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Cough and sore throat.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer. She is currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. Biopsy of a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports good support from family members and nursing staff.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.
Respiratory: Reports minimal cough and sore throat. Denies shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea or vomiting. Reports decreased appetite.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Neck
- Examination: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Crackles bilaterally.

Skin
- Examination: Erythema on the anterior side of the chest on the left side.

Lower Extremities
- Examination: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Lung cancer.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy and radiation for stage three non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Treatment: Continue current chemotherapy regimen (cisplatin and etoposide) and radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion of treatment to assess tumor response and potential for surgical resection.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's cough and bilateral crackles on lung exam are likely due to mild radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation.

3. Sore throat and painful swallowing.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's sore throat is likely due to inflammation from radiation treatment.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times a day to alleviate pain and facilitate eating and drinking.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low immunoglobulin A level.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports recent international travel to Zambia. Family owns a donut shop.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and started on metformin.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of immune deficiencies.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever.
Respiratory: Lungs clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Gastrointestinal: Abdomen soft, non-tender.

VITALS

Vitals reviewed and within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.

Gastrointestinal
- Abdominal Exam: Soft, non-tender.

Lymphatic
- Neck Exam: No lymphadenopathy.

LAB RESULTS

Recent lab work consistent with IgA deficiency.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Low immunoglobulin A level.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's lab work shows IgA deficiency, which is a common immunodeficiency. Patient does not report frequent infections or other concerning symptoms.
- Additional Testing: Order further blood work to check for other immunodeficiencies.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the nature of IgA deficiency and advised the patient to watch for infections that do not resolve or worsen. Instructed the patient to inform healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they ever need blood products.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended assessment and plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient has been experiencing right elbow pain for approximately 4 days. He reports that the pain is located on the inside of his elbow and can radiate down into his forearm. The patient denies any trauma or previous injury to the right elbow. He has been engaging in pottery work recently, which may have contributed to the pain. The patient rates the pain as a 6 out of 10 and reports that it interferes with his daily activities and sleep. He has tried ibuprofen with minimal relief.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has been engaging in pottery work during the pandemic.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain radiating into the forearm.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Within normal limits.
MSK: 
Examination of the right elbow: Pain to palpation along the medial aspect. Pain with pronation. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Right medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we discussed the current symptoms and the following plan:
1. Rest the right elbow and wear a sling while awake.
2. Apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes, three times a day.
3. Take ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for one week.
4. Avoid pottery work for the next couple of weeks.
5. Follow-up appointment in one week to evaluate progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up after a fall and chest pain.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath.
Genitourinary: Denies urinary incontinence.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: 98.7 degrees F
Heart Rate: 72 bpm
Oxygen Saturation: 96%

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, abnormal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to have been caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting sodium intake. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed dietary modifications as noted above.
- Medical Treatment: Continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain is intermittent and comes and goes. He experiences burning sensation during urination and his urine appears darker than usual. He has taken Tylenol for pain relief, but it has not been effective. He feels nauseated but has not vomited. He has a family history of kidney stones and has had them in the past. A recent CT scan ordered by his primary care doctor revealed a kidney stone.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Reports nausea.
Urinary: Reports burning sensation during urination.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
CVA: Positive tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

The CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm stone located in the proximal right ureter. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Right kidney stone.

PLAN

1. Encourage the patient to push fluids to facilitate urination and help pass the stone.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. The patient may continue to take Tylenol for breakthrough pain.
3. Provide a strainer for the patient to use when urinating to catch the stone for further testing.
4. Order a Basic Metabolic Panel (BMP), urinalysis, and urine culture to evaluate for any signs of infection.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 1 to 2 weeks to check on his progress. If his symptoms have not improved, further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy will be discussed. The patient should contact the doctor if symptoms worsen.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents today with a non-healing right foot ulcer. He has had the ulcer for approximately six weeks, which he first noticed after wearing a tight pair of shoes. The ulcer initially presented as a blister with stinging pain, but has since worsened with blackened skin around the wound, calf muscle cramping, and a red streak along the inside of his calf muscle. The patient has been on antibiotics for six days and has experienced some improvement, but still has significant pain and discomfort. He also reports recent difficulty catching his breath and coughing.

His blood sugar has been trending higher than normal in the past few weeks, with occasional spikes up to 500. His last A1c was 6.7.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hiking and recently hiked a new trail before the onset of the ulcer.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Patient reports fever and chills.
Cardiovascular: No chest pain.
Respiratory: Patient reports coughing and difficulty catching breath.
Skin: Patient reports non-healing right foot ulcer.
Neurological: No numbness or tingling reported.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure: Not provided
Heart rate: Not provided

PHYSICAL EXAM

Foot exam: 2x2 cm necrotic wound on right heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, erythemia, and odor. No bony exposure. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer
2. Diabetes
3. Possible cellulitis

PLAN

1. Order test to check blood supply for the wound.
2. Perform debridement in the office today.
3. Obtain culture and consider adjusting antibiotic therapy based on results.
4. Monitor redness and swelling in the calf.
5. Follow up in seven days.
6. Recommend patient to follow up with endocrinologist for diabetes management.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports a tick bite on his right knee, which occurred over a week ago. He spends time outdoors, including hunting and yard work. The bite area is warm, burning, and annoying. No fever or chills reported. Patient has had tick bites in the past but has never been diagnosed with Lyme disease.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension: Controlled with lisinopril 20 mg daily.
Diabetes: Controlled with metformin 1000 mg twice daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or body aches.
Musculoskeletal: Reports arthritic pain in joints.
Neurological: Reports headache and general malaise since tick bite.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Respiration: Not reported
Temperature: 98.4°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Full range of motion in right knee. Pain to palpation of right anterior knee.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash over right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Tick bite and possible Lyme disease.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient presents with a tick bite on the right knee and a bull's-eye rash, which raises concern for Lyme disease.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm Lyme disease.
- Medical Treatment: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for three weeks.

2. Hypertension.
- Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily.
- Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes.
- Continue metformin 1000 mg twice daily.
- Order hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control.
- Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.
